pullRequest.body:
Some initial definitions introducing a model of oracle computability via partial recursive functions, define Turing reducibility and equivalence, and prove that Turing equivalence is an equivalence relation. Define the type of Turing degrees as equivalence classes under Turing equivalence. This PR includes:

- `RecursiveIn g f`: An inductive definition representing that a partial function `f` is recursive in oracle `g`.
- `turing_reducible`: A relation defining Turing reducibility between partial functions.
- `turing_equivalent`: A relation defining Turing equivalence between partial functions.
- `TuringDegree`: The type of Turing degrees, defined as equivalence classes under `turing_equivalent`.
- A proof that TuringDegree is a partial order when reducibility is lifted to degrees

### Implementation Notes

The type `RecursiveIn g f` is inductively defined to include basic functions such as `zero`, `succ`, projections, and the oracle `g`, and is closed under pairing, composition, primitive recursion, and μ-recursion. The `join` operation combines two partial functions by mapping even and odd numbers to the respective functions.

### Notation

- `f ≤ᵀ g`: `f` is Turing reducible to `g`.
- `f ≡ᵀ g`: `f` is Turing equivalent to `g`.
- `f ⊔ g`: The join of partial functions `f` and `g`.

## In Progress
The work here is just the basic definitions for the theory being developed. Some current in-progress work involves proving the upper-semilattice structure of Turing degrees, proving the existence of a _relativized_ universal partial recursive function, and proving properties of the jump operator.

### References

* [Carneiro2018] Carneiro, Mario. *Formalizing Computability Theory via Partial Recursive Functions*. arXiv preprint arXiv:1810.08380, 2018.
* [Odifreddi1989] Odifreddi, Piergiorgio. *Classical Recursion Theory: The Theory of Functions and Sets of Natural Numbers, Vol. I*. Springer-Verlag, 1989.
* [Soare1987] Soare, Robert I. *Recursively Enumerable Sets and Degrees*. Springer-Verlag, 1987.
* [Gu2015] Gu, Yi-Zhi. *Turing Degrees*. Institute for Advanced Study, 2015.

### Tags

Computability, Oracle, Turing Degrees, Reducibility, Equivalence Relation

nodes.body: Due to limitations with Mathlib's CI there is a problem with merging PRs from forks - could you please request write access to the mathlib repository on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/github.20permission) and move this contribution to a branch of it, as described in [here](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html)? Thanks!
I've just noticed that this PR comes from a fork, as opposed to a branch. Unfortunately our CI cannot support this setup, so please follow the contribution guide to get access to non-master branches.
Perhaps the definition of `Nat.Partrec` should be changed to this, otherwise there's unnecessary duplication.
Going to add an alternative definition, Partrec_0, defined in this way
That's not a good solution, it would just mean we have two duplicate definitions

Is it best to just remove these equivalence lemmas then? I don't want to mess too much with the existing computability set up. These lemmas end up being useful for some proofs I'm currently working on.
Is this definition needed? Can't you directly use `RecursiveIn`, perhaps changing the order of arguments?
Having this as shorthand does make things convenient. Do you think it's necessary to remove?

I think in the long run either it won't be convenient because either stuff will have to be duplicated with `turing_reducible` and `RecursiveIn`, or everything will use one of these, and then you might as well only define it
Fixed in the latest push, thank you
Another potential spelling is `AntisymmRel RecursiveIn`, and then you get that this is an equivalence relation from showing that `RecursiveIn` is a preorder

Mathlib style uses focusing dots instead of braces
```suggestion
  · intro pF
```

This duplicates `partrec_iff_partrec_in_zero`, perhaps first prove `Nat.Partrec f -> ∀ g, RecursiveIn g f` and `RecursiveIn (fun _ => pure 0) f -> Nat.Partrec f` and conclude both iffs from these two implications?
This docstring doesn't look accurate - it doesn't describe the `.map (fun x => 2 * x)` on the result of `f` and the `.map (fun y => 2 * y + 1)` on the result of `g`.
This collides with the notation for `sup`.

This can be `Antisymmetrization _ RecursiveIn` ([Antisymmetrization](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Antisymmetrization.html#Antisymmetrization)). This also automatically gives a `PartialOrder` from [instPartialOrderAntisymmetrization](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Antisymmetrization.html#instPartialOrderAntisymmetrization)
The name of the type here seems out of sync with the theorem names. I can't comment on which of the two is better.
Just fixed naming discrepancies in latest commit

```suggestion
theorem RecursiveIn.refl (f : ℕ →. ℕ) : RecursiveIn f f :=
```
lets you write `.refl _` in some contexts

```suggestion
def TuringEquivalent (f g : ℕ →. ℕ) : Prop :=
```
as this is a `Prop`. The lemmas about it should either be called `TuringEquivalent.foo` or `turingEquivalent_foo`.

This can be renamed to allow for dot-notation
```suggestion
lemma Nat.Partrec.recursiveIn (f : ℕ →. ℕ) (pF : Nat.Partrec f) (g : ℕ →. ℕ) : RecursiveIn f g := by
```

This can be renamed to allow for dot-notation
```suggestion
lemma RecursiveIn.partrec_of_zero (f : ℕ →. ℕ) (fRecInZero : RecursiveIn f fun _ => Part.some 0) :
    Nat.Partrec f := by
```

This is mostly stylistic, but this can be golfed to
```suggestion
theorem partrec_iff_partrec_in_everything (f : ℕ →. ℕ) : Nat.Partrec f ↔ ∀ g, RecursiveIn f g :=
  ⟨(·.recursiveIn), (· _ |>.partrec_of_zero)⟩
```
If you provide an `IsRefl` instance for `RecursiveIn` this can be [antisymmRel_refl](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Antisymmetrization.html#antisymmRel_refl)
This can be [AntisymmRel.symm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Antisymmetrization.html#AntisymmRel.symm)
Perhaps this should be an `abbrev` instead of a `def`?
This should be an `abbrev`, not a `def`
The indentation of this is incorrect, it should be indented by two spaces

In general instead of writing function types and then using `intro` you can introduce values directly as arguments - often this is cleaner.
```suggestion
@[trans]
theorem RecursiveIn.trans {f g h : ℕ →. ℕ} (hg : RecursiveIn f g) (hh : RecursiveIn g h) :
    RecursiveIn f h := by
```
If you provide an `IsTrans` instance for `RecursiveIn` this can be [AntisymmRel.trans](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Antisymmetrization.html#AntisymmRel.trans)
If you provide an `IsPreorder` instance for `RecursiveIn` this can be `(AntisymmRel.setoid _ _).iseqv`

```suggestion
    Nat.Partrec f := by
```

I think `TuringEquivalent.trans`, `TuringEquivalent.refl` and `TuringEquivalent.symm` should all be delayed after this and deduced from the `Equivalence` directly.
Additionally, `Transitive` is only used in few places, I think it will be better to phrase `TuringEquivalent.trans` directly in terms of `a ≡ᵀ b -> b ≡ᵀ c -> a ≡ᵀ c` (mostly for dot notation).

```suggestion
Instance declaring that `TuringEquivalent` is an equivalence relation.
```

```suggestion
Custom infix notation for `TuringEquivalent`.
```
You should either reintroduce this notation or remove this line
This collides with the notation for [Sum](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs//Init/Core.html#Sum). Perhaps `join` (and notation for it, if necessary) could wait for a later PR?
Yeah, this isn't needed in this PR, I'll remove.

```suggestion
- `TuringEquivalent`: A relation defining Turing equivalence between partial functions.
```

```suggestion
  The type of Turing degrees, defined as equivalence classes under `TuringEquivalent`.
```
Perhaps this will be easier to use with `g` as an explicit parameter?

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability): define oracle computability and Turing degrees
